what what makes Kieran tick will she

I'm Becky I'm a seconde student here at
HBS um and so when Kieran and I talked
as she mentioned we talked about the
importance of sort of intergenerational
feminist relationships and for me um I
haven't had very many female mentors
I've been in very predominantly male
environments and so this queen be talk
resonated quite a bit um so I wanted to
talk about three female relationships
that each modeled opportunities because
for me being able to imagine something
I'm not a really creative person but
being able to see something makes it
more concrete and more possible um so
the the there are three relationships
that have each sort of opened up for me
the opportunities of what the world had
to offer and the first one is uh about
my mom so my dad is incredibly
professionally successful he's a
journalist he has moved his way up from
being you know on the assignment's desk
to being bureau chief of an important
Bureau um and now he's the one they call
in when there's emergencies he's gotten
promotions and awards but everybody who
knows my parents knows that my mom is
the smart one um and there's no like
it's not a joke like everybody knows
that they're like oh Fred's great but
like il's the smart one um and that was
the dynamic that I grew up with at home
that Mom was smart and academic and
there was no like there was no question
in anyone's mind um the best example of
this is I'm a little bit mathy not a
math major but more so than people often
expect from their female child and I'd
ask my dad for help and he'd say math
wasn't invented when I was in school and
my my mom would roll her eyes she be
like math was invented in ancient Greece
which also may not be correct
but anyway so um what this modeled for
me is that it was tot it was an
acceptable model of female intelligence
it was okay to be good at school um and
that was really important to me because
like Kieran I had uh I grew up abroad
and I moved back to the United States
when I was 16 and I moved back to
Springfield Virginia a town nobody has
probably heard of oh yeah a DC residents
now okay so I went to a really big
public school um and and there were
where we were very clearly tracked like
you were on the honors track or you were
on the remedial track or you were on the
normal kid track and everybody knew who
was in each track cuz you knew and there
were sort of two or three models for
female intelligence if you were a smart
girl you could be um a geek like really
nerdy and like an indoor kid um you
could hide it as successfully as you
could it worked better if you were
really pretty or good at sports or you
could be brassy um and well let's just
put that as as how I was described we'll
put that gently um and and I found that
that chafed um but every night I was
able to come home and talk to my mom be
like you know I want to participate in
class but I don't want to be this person
and she said you know you don't always
have to be this person you know my mom
is my mom is incredibly shy and so my
mom worked for many years and then uh
became a stay-at-home mom after she sort
of ramped down
um for a number of reasons and one of
them is that her model of female
intelligence was very difficult in the
in her Generation Um she's incredibly
shy and she's in she hates competition
and she would tell me stories of she was
a biology major and she switched to
English because this was during a time
when um admission to medical school was
so competitive that if you left your
notes out people would steal them and
rip them up and she just opted out of
that that whole system and so while I
saw that it was okay to be smart I
didn't see a way to be ambitious or
driven um and this is no way a failing
of my mother she's an excellent woman
but it was a difficult position for her
and it made it difficult for me so I
went to a women's college to Barnard um
where all of a sudden everybody in the
room was a smart woman and so you could
be whatever you wanted so I tried
everything I played rugby and I joined a
religious group and I joined a political
group and you could be whatever it was
aside from being a smart woman um and in
that time I um the I met the second
foundational relationship for me uh her
name is Dasha she's a holocaust Survivor
who I met through derot which is in New
York and intergenerational it exists
solely to create intergenerational
relationships primarily so that elderly
and homebound seniors um who don't have
family can have somebody visit them on a
regular basis and so for the 10 years
years that I lived in New York um I
visited her every Sunday and so she and
I are both part of the same incredibly
traditional uh religious group where uh
family values are what you would expect
them to be the women tend to take if
they take a job a second career job um
one that's more flexible and allows a
lot more room um you expect one of the
ways that you choose a life partner is
is an economic analysis uh that sounds a
little crass but you you think about
these things like when I'm marrying if
I'm going to be a teacher and they're
going to be a teacher how's that going
to work out like it's a it's a
consideration it's a very traditional in
group um and she raised her son Alone um
she got divorced in a time when when
divorce was completely unacceptable um
and she raised him from the time he was
six or seven all the way through
adulthood and sent him off to school and
she works and continues she's in her 80s
now and she goes to work three days a
week and what she showed for me is the a
model of female
self-sufficiency of that you could do
something that you enjoyed and sometimes
that you didn't enjoy and that work was
work um and that that was okay for a
woman you didn't have to follow your
passion to the exclusion of economic
importance but you also didn't have to
think only about what was going to make

was a big it was very eye openening
especially as I see my female um my

out or ramp down for a variety of
different reasons um and some of them
some of them not and so we have these

are you know how do we model in whatever

I mentioned since I'm from this
community and I worked in pretty
exclusively male dominated environments
um i' never had a female Mentor I had a
terrific male boss before I came to HBS
um who supported me in ways that I
didn't know I needed to be supported and
modeled actually he was a really strong

because he was a boy scout Cub leader um
and when his wife called he always
picked up the phone and so it created
this normaly around the importance of

he would treat other people's
commitments that weren't necessarily
family as just as important because
that's another way to be inclusive and
it sort of modeled this interesting
Behavior which was great but he was not
able to model for me what it could be
like for me he had been very successful
he had worked his way up but he had
worked in ways that would have been
unsustainable for me as a woman who
wants to and will soon have kids and a

what have I done um and am I going to be
the only I'm what what have I done how
is this life going to be sustainable and
so actually my my sister-in-law SE who
is
also a great feminist and a great leader
she sat down to me and she said you know
in 20 years you're going to be going to
talk to people about you know how I you
know how difficult it was and how great
there are so many more I was like I hope
so but I was pretty panicked and I came
to Boston one of the nice things about
HBS is that it is so intentionally diver
but the downside of this as Kieran and I
had discussed a little bit was that
everybody can start to feel like an N of
one like you're the only person who is

sometimes it can be incredibly isolating

leader of my religious group and I said
um how many women have graduated from
HBS from our group in the last 15 years
he said including you and the other

one okay so uh so at this point I was
like okay at least somebody else has
done it um and when I I I went to
religious Services one morning and
someone said to me you know you should
meet Debbie Debbie went to HBS and I
said okay that's it like I don't care
what she does I don't care if she worked
for 10 minutes like I have to meet this
woman um so I went to go uh so I went to
go talk to her and at this point I had
sort of built up this idea that there
were careers that I couldn't do that
wouldn't work for me and for my
lifestyle and I went to talk to her and
she has been on the executive committee
of one of the biggest consulting firms
um she's had a fabulous career and has
raised four kids with a husband who
works and I was like oh maybe there is
something else I can do um and she she
refers to herself as the queen of
leaning in and um has sort of opened up
to me this idea that I could do whatever
I want there's nothing that's off the

that I should be aware this I sound like
a first year lead class but um that I
should be aware in every moment what is
the choice I'm making and what I'm
balancing and that those choices don't
have to be forever or even for long term
but that every day you should be aware
of what choice you're making and
modeling that make that choice making
successfully has sort of opened up my
ideas of you know maybe maybe I could be
a CEO maybe if that's what I wanted it
would be possible
and I don't have to put off the rest of
my life am I going to be the youngest
CEO already not but you know I could get
there if that's something I wanted and I
wouldn't necessarily have to give up who
I am um and so being able to see those
sort of three different ideas of
opportunities and seeing what they could
mean um has been really helpful for me
and hopefully um as we see more women at

options and because it's easier to
follow a path if you can see somebody
who's done
